awd_titl_txt: Combinatorial Properties of Convex Sets and Measures in Euclidean spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Discrete geometry and topological combinatorics are important areas of mathematics.  They highlight connections between different areas of mathematics in novel ways.  The research in these subjects has applications in computer science, such as in search algorithms and optimization.  This award will support the PI's research to develop new mathematical methods to solve problems on the boundary of combinatorics and topology.  Problems in discrete geometry are often easy to state, and a good subject for popularization of mathematics. The PI will aim at involving undergraduate students in his research. 

The research of this project will focus on three main types of open problems.  These type of problems highlight different aspects of discrete geometry and are multi-disciplinary; involving combinatorics, topology and linear algebra.  As they are closely related, progress in one area will benefit the research in the others.  The first kind of problems, partitions of measures, is a cornerstone of the interaction of equivariant topology and discrete geometry.  The PI will focus on the effect of additional geometric constraints to classic problems in the field.  The second is Tverberg theory, which focuses on understanding the convex hulls of finite sets of points from a combinatorial point of view.  The PI has extended the linear-algebraic methods used for this area, and aims at working on topological versions of recent results.  The third kind focuses on understanding the intersection structure of finite families of convex sets in Euclidean spaces.  The work will focus on continuing a recent trend of developing quantitative versions of classic results, such as Helly-type theorems.  Several of these problems have as additional motivation applications in computer science and other areas of mathematics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this project aimed to study the interaction of several fields in mathematics: combinatorics, discrete geometry, and topology. The PI selected three areas (Tverberg theory, partitions of measures, and combinatorial properties of convex sets) in which such connections are particularly relevant.  

Intellectual merits:

The PI carried out the proposed research successfully.  In collaboration with F. Frick, the PI extended known cases of the topological Tverberg theorem even if the parameters are not prime powers.  This circumvents one of the most significant obstacles in the area.  We expect these methods to be useful in other problems in topological combinatorics. 
In collaboration with S. Sarkar, the PI extended the linear algebraic methods of Sarkaria to be amenable to probabilistic arguments. In the area of combinatorial properties of convex sets, the PI exhibited strong links of these problems with functional analysis, producing many "quantitative versions" of Helly-type results. The PI proved some of the first "colorful" versions of quantitative Helly results. The use of topological methods in these problems is new and exciting.
In mass partitions, the PI wrote an extensive survey of the topic with Edgardo Roldán-Pensado, which includes several new results and describes promising open problems in the field. In collaboration with Alexander Xue, the PI extended known results regarding partitions of sets of points in the plane to partitions of sets of lines.The PI also obtained new results regarding the possible symmetric structure of polytopes in collaborations with A. Chirvasitu, F. Ladisch, E. Schulte, and G. I. Williams. In total, the PI produced ten research papers with the support of this project.

Broader Impacts:

The PI was able to support and mentor undergraduate students in research. Five of the research papers produced during this period were in collaboration with undergraduate students of different universities. In addition, 60% of the undergraduate students that collaborated with the PI are women. This is part of an ongoing yearly summer program at Baruch College for undergraduate students to do research in mathematics.Not only has this summer program produce impressive research by undergraduates, but the participants have also been motivated to continue their careers in mathematics and have been accepted to prestigious graduate programs.
All the research produced with the support of NSF has been accessible to the public in arXiv and presented at national conferences, international conferences, and research seminars at US institutions.
